title: Scientists find that teabags release billions of tiny plastic particles into your cup of tea
text:
Plastic could be polluting your builder's brew, scientists warn, as they find popular plastic tea bags release billions of tiny fragments into the liquid when left to steep.

Teabags made from plastic — rather than the traditional paper — have become increasingly common.

However, plastic degrades with time, breaking down into tiny micro- and nano-sized particles than can be over 750 times smaller than the width of a human hair.

The researchers also found that water fleas exposed to the plastic debris from the teabags went on to grow abnormally and exhibit unusual behaviours.

The exact impact on humans of ingesting micro- and nanoplastic particles, however, is not yet known.

This finding adds to the locations where these minuscule plastic pollutants have been detected — which also include foodstuffs, the environment and aquatic life.

Plastic particles could be polluting your builder's brew, scientists warn, as they find that plastic tea bags release billions of tiny pieces when left to steep

Chemical engineer Laura Hernandez and colleagues at Canada's McGill University bought four different commercially-sold teas from coffee shops and grocery stores in Montreal for their analysis.

The researchers cut open each bag and washed them to remove the tea leaves and any debris.

The team then simulated the tea-brewing process by heating the empty tea bags in water at 203°F (95°C) for five minutes before analysing the resulting water contents under an electron microscope.

'Steeping a single plastic teabag at brewing temperature releases approximately 11.6 billion microplastics and 3.1 billion nanoplastics into a single cup of the beverage,' the researchers wrote in their paper.

These levels of plastic pollution are thousands of times higher than those that have been previously reported in other foodstuffs.

Analysing samples of the tiny plastic bits, the researchers found that the composition of the released particles matched that of the original teabags themselves, being made from nylon and polyethylene terephthalate (PET).

PET is the most common of the polyester family of heat-softening plastics.

In a second experiment, the researchers exposed water fleas to various doses of the teabag-derived micro- and nanoplastics to see what effect such might have.

Water fleas — or Daphnia magna — are model organisms that are often used in environmental studies.

The researchers found that, although the animals survived after exposure to the pollutants, they did show various anatomical and behavioural abnormalities.

For example, some of the fleas failed to develop a normal upper shell, instead forming an inflated balloon sack that ended up suspended over the animal.

Additionally, some of the polluted water fleas were seen to swim for much longer distances than their unaffected counterparts.

The researchers also found that water fleas exposed to the plastic debris from the teabags went on to grow abnormally and exhibit unusual behaviours

The exact impact of taking in such tiny debris in your tea, however, remains unclear.

'The knowledge on adverse effects of plastic particles on human health is still lacking and there is an urgent need to investigate potential toxic mechanisms in higher vertebrates and humans,' the researchers concluded.

This, they added, will be of 'vital importance when assessing the human health risk of micro- and nanoplastics.'

The full findings of the study were published in the journal Environmental Science & Technology.
